image.altText: A composite image of a man holding knife and man with surfboard

props.synopsis: A month ago, Joel Cauchi's parents were relieved to see a text message showing him enjoying life at the beach. Next time they saw him it was on national television as he attacked people in a Sydney shopping centre.

title.children: Bondi attacker's path from finding new 'life' to murdering six people after ceasing medication

image.altText: An image of Brittany Higgins next to an image of Bruce Lehrmann.

props.synopsis: Justice Michael Lee leaned in to the Shakespearean tragedy of Bruce Lehrmann's case and with the narrative muscularity of a literary thriller showed simplicity and complexity need not be enemies. As his judgment took form it became clear he had an altogether more useful verdict in mind.

title.children: The power of the Lehrmann judgment is in its nuance. Let it be a lesson to us all

image.altText: Three faces from the community

props.synopsis: For many in Sydney's Assyrian community, the images of violence at the Christ The Good Shepherd Church on Monday evening brought flashbacks of war.

title.children: 'It's like an exposed nerve': Assyrians express raw emotions following Sydney stabbing and riot

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann outside the ACT Supreme Court with a serious expression, wearing glasses and a tie. He has a beard.

props.synopsis: What happened between Bruce Lehrmann and Brittany Higgins in a ministerial suite at Parliament House in March 2019 has triggered at least a dozen avenues of legal action so far — and the costs of all this litigation are set to be many millions.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's costs in failed defamation case set to be astronomically high

image.altText: A wombat with grey fur, black eyes and large square-shaped claws in a fenced-in enclosure, with grass and tunnel made of wood.

props.synopsis: Found as an orphan in Tasmania in 1989, Wain the wombat — also known as Mr Wine — is shuffling toward his mid-30s at a zoo in Japan, exceeding the average age of his wild counterparts by an estimated 20 years.

title.children: Lovingly known as 'Mr Wine', the world's oldest-known wombat about to turn 35

image.altText: The exterior of the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre, with barbed wire in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A royal commission recommended the notorious detention centre on Darwin's outskirts be closed by February 2018, and the government has repeatedly said it intends to demolish it once children are transferred to a new facility.

title.children: NT Corrections exploring keeping Don Dale open as women's prison

image.altText: A man looks at stock prices through the window of the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is trading flat on Wednesday as investors ponder global interest rates after comments by the US Federal Reserve suggesting inflation hasn't been hosed down. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Supermarket inquiry slammed as 'populism' as former ACCC chair ponders if retailers are actually gouging

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Cracks starting to appear, as insolvencies hit record high
Senate inquiry into supermarket pricing labelled 'political opportunism'
Australia getting its first high-purity alumina processing facility

props.synopsis: The AFP Victim Identification Team are often parents themselves, tasked with solving some of the most grim and shocking crimes humans commit. For them, disconnecting from work is a necessity.

title.children: Sergeant Kate Laidler trained to be a PE teacher. She never imagined spending her work days tracking down predators

image.altText: Julian Assange looks to the camera as he is photographed from behind glass with graffiti etched into it. His grey hair is back.

props.synopsis: Julian Assange's bid to avoid extradition to America is dealt a blow, as lawyers for the United States provide the assurances about his treatment that a London court had demanded.

title.children: Assange's family in 'extreme distress' as US responds to UK court's extradition demands

image.altText: Nick Riewoldt jogs off the field flanked by two trainers during an AFL game.

props.synopsis: St Kilda champion Nick Riewoldt praises Nathan Murphy and Angus Brayshaw for being "pioneers" of an era where players put their health and wellbeing first.

title.children: 'I don't care what the rest of my life looks ﻿like': Riewoldt happy to see AFL players no longer thinking like he did

image.altText: A large room filled with cushions placed in a circle.

props.synopsis: A 53-year-old Melbourne woman has died after ingesting a drink at a regional Victorian wellness centre offering "alternative and holistic health services". Here's what we know.

title.children: A woman has died after consuming a drink made with mushrooms at a wellness retreat — here's what we know

image.altText: An oil sketch of donald trump wearing a blue suit looking upset

props.synopsis: Seven jury members are selected on the second day of Donald Trump's trial at the Manhattan Criminal Court where he is charged with falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal.

title.children: Trump told off for 'muttering' as first jurors selected in hush money trial

image.altText: Two young women of Latin American background standing in front of a boat on a sunny day

props.synopsis: The return of international tourists to Australia appears to be stalling, with numbers almost 30 per cent down on 2019. So how do we get them back?

title.children: Four years after COVID shuttered borders, millions of international tourists are nowhere to be seen

image.altText: Paul Altimore standing at a lecturn delivering a speech next to table with photo of Private Halliday and other personal objects

props.synopsis: Private William Halliday's ashes couldn't be reunited with relatives, but a military funeral on Tuesday put him to rest after an exhaustive search and more than 15 years after he passed.

title.children: Former soldier and his dog finally laid to rest after attempt to find family ends

image.altText: people wearing masks stand in a queue along a fenceline

props.synopsis: A research team uses a computer simulation to predict what the death toll would have been among older Australians without any vaccine campaign at all.

title.children: Australia's vaccine campaign likely prevented almost 18,000 COVID-19 deaths in NSW, new report says

image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds up a dollar coin while standing in the House of Representatives

props.synopsis: The good news is there's likely to be some change to Australia's HELP scheme, and we're likely to hear about it soon, in the lead-up to the May budget. The bad news for borrowers is it won't be debt relief of the kind Biden is offering.

title.children: Albanese's budget will likely include changes to student debt. Here's what that could look like

image.altText: donkey on conveyor belt

props.synopsis: A live toad, holy water from the Ganges and an aphrodisiac made from donkeys are among the more unusual items detected at Australian airports and mail centres.

title.children: Airports caught thousands of travellers with biosecurity risks in 2023, including holy water from the Ganges

image.altText: A young girl named Taylah Payne smiles while holding a skateboard as another person skates behind her.

props.synopsis: One of the world's most coveted urban skateboarding locations is facing an uncertain future, as Perth property developers plan to turn the site into a retail and commercial office space.

title.children: It's skaters vs developers as locals fight to stop a global skateboarding mecca being turned into retail hub

image.altText: A man and a woman carry a historical painting down the street.

props.synopsis: Bystanders have joined workers to try to save art in Copenhagen's Old Stock Exchange building after a blaze engulfed its spire. Here's what we know.

title.children: Pedestrians rush into historic Copenhagen building to save artwork from blaze

image.altText: An ad on Facebook featuring Dr Karl's image to promote a health product

props.synopsis: Scammers on Facebook and Instagram are using a fake, AI-generated Dr Karl to sell health pills to Australians. When users reported the ads to Meta, the company initially said there was nothing wrong with them.

title.children: A fake AI-generated Dr Karl is scamming Australians and the real Dr Karl can't stop it

image.altText: Sparsely stocked supermarket shelves.

props.synopsis: Dairy products, meat and other groceries are set to remain in limited supply across Western Australia for at least another week, as supermarkets struggle to recover after widespread flooding cut off critical transport routes last month.

title.children: More empty shelves ahead in WA supermarkets as Coles and Woolworths try to restock stores

image.altText: A crowd of people at a music festival in front of a stage

props.synopsis: Organisers of the touring Pandemonium Rocks music festival are refusing full refunds to ticket holders after major changes to the event, despite stipulations in Australian Consumer Law.

title.children: Hundreds of people found their favourite band was dropped from a festival. Can they get a refund?

image.altText: A young woman comforts an older man holding a stress ball

props.synopsis: Older Australians fear their voices are being drowned out in favour of powerful industry groups who have greater influence over government.

title.children: You might have missed them, but here are some of the big changes coming in aged care

image.altText: Youth matter

props.synopsis: The now-expired Alice Springs youth curfew has triggered mixed reactions, lauded as a "circuit-breaker" by some and a "punitive", "knee-jerk" response by others. Here's a look back at what we learned.

title.children: The youth curfew in Alice Springs has ended. So what did we learn?

image.altText: A composite image of three historical buildings, hills and clouds

props.synopsis: On Tasmania's wild west coast, towns have risen and fallen at the whim of industry. Some of their oldest living inhabitants remember their former homes, and how their communities came undone.

title.children: Tasmania is riddled with hundreds of fading and vanishing towns. Where did they go wrong?

image.altText: a bishop at an assyrian orthodox church during a service before a person approaches and allegedley stabs him

props.synopsis: The teenager who allegedly attacked a bishop at a church in Sydney was placed on a good behaviour bond after being convicted of a knife crime three months ago, the ABC can reveal.

title.children: Teenager accused of church attack received good behaviour bond for knife crime

image.altText: The High Court on the shores of Lake Burley Griffin. There are dark clouds over the building, and a seagull in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for an Iranian man refusing to cooperate with efforts to deport him will make their arguments before the High Court today, demanding his release to the community.

title.children: The High Court will today hear a case of a migrant resisting deportation, which could have far-reaching implications

image.altText: A man with a helmet on is standing inside a processing plant.

props.synopsis: Critical minerals projects in Queensland and South Australia will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in federal government loans as part of the government's plan for a "future made in Australia".

title.children: Critical minerals projects to receive $585 million in federal government loans

image.altText: A line of voters wait next a to a sign directing people where to vote.

props.synopsis: Voters in Solomon Islands will head to the polls today for an election that will be closely watched across the world, ending weeks of campaigning for candidates who have crisscrossed the sprawling archipelago. But the struggle to win government is far from over.

title.children: It's election day in Solomon Islands – and a political shock is not impossible

image.altText: A woman stares ahead in a rioting city, wearing a blue press jacket sayign press. She has a camera around her.

props.synopsis: Called "irresponsible" and potentially "dangerous" simply based on its trailer, Civil War is a blockbuster that defies easy moral interpretation.

title.children: Kirsten Dunst says 'there's never been a movie' like Civil War

image.altText: Colourful squares and decorations on tables beside beige curtains in a room with plenty of natural light.

props.synopsis: Police are investigating the death of a 53-year-old Victorian woman who fell ill after consuming a drink at a retreat in the regional town of Clunes, north of Ballarat.

title.children: Police investigate death of woman who fell ill after consuming drink at Victorian wellness retreat

image.altText: Bruce looks serious as he walks through a throng of reporters, wearing suit and tie.

props.synopsis: Now might be a good time to reflect on how devotedly and brutally mastheads and prominent commentators seek to undermine, discredit and destroy women who allege sexual assault, or report on it.

title.children: How rape can be turned into a culture war boggles the mind. But this case was politicised at the starting gate

image.altText: A man wearing a Woolworths polo shirt with the name tag 'Brad' stands in a supermarket.

props.synopsis: Woolworths boss Brad Banducci was warned he could face six months in prison or a $5,000 fine if he was held in contempt by the Senate for failing to answer questions at the inquiry into supermarket pricing.

title.children: Greens senator threatens Woolworths CEO with six months in prison for contempt of Senate

image.altText: A man at the top of an escalator holds a bollard, to holds back a man with a knife

props.synopsis: A petition was set up by a member of the public calling for him to be granted an Australian citizenship, describing his actions as a "true act of Australianism".

title.children: Bondi attack 'bollard man' to be granted permanent residency in Australia, lawyer says
